results.title: [Ted Parsons Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
Ted Parsons was a keen amateur filmmaker of the 1940s to 1960s. Ted’s films feature life in and around the Victorian regional city of Wangaratta post-war. This was a period of prosperity and optimism largely due to a successful textile industry that took Wangaratta from a small country town to major rural city, declared in 1959.

Ted captures the many sporting and social events, venues and clubs, holidays and travel along with scenes of everyday life. The collection also shows the broader issues faced by country people such as the regular flooding events around the Ovens and King Rivers.

Wangaratta’s success story as a manufacturing town traces the path of post-war migration and the accompanying growth of Australia’s economy, which makes these films particularly interesting.

The Ted Parsons Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s grandson Barry Parsons. The films have been made on 16mm film.

This films contains scenes at the lawn bowling clubs in and around Wangaratta. As a testament to playing sport or bowls as in this example, the players are older but look very spry and nimble. Also of note, it is not unusual to see players with cigarettes and both players and spectators are very ‘natty’ dressers.

Note that at 00:27:04:00 the film changes to black and white for some minutes and some scenes are repeated.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 sign and gateway for Wangaratta Bowling Club followed by a women’s tournament
00:00:51:00 a great example of bowling and two bowlers smiling at the camera
00:01:01:00 a bowler checks in on a room of tables set for a meal
00:01:47:00 a Californian Bungalow architectural style house in the background
00:02:45:00 bowling toward the camera
00:03:16:00 a cheery smile at the camera
00:03:39:00 men join the bowling green with one bowler encouraging the ball by clicking over his head whilst smoking through a cigarette holder
00:05:05:00 bowlers crossing the green
00:05:54:00 a men’s tournament
00:06:18:00 children and their dog watch the tournament
00:06:31:00 poster for ‘Benalla Bowling Carnival New Year Week-End’ followed by Benalla bowling green and some spectators
00:07:51:00 bowlers refreshing themselves with some beer
00:09:00:00 a crowd dressed for an occasion
00:09:20:00 some dignatories stand in front of bowlers and one of the women bowls what is likely to be an opening shot of the tournament
00:10:10:00 some lovely 1950s style hats worn by members of the watching crowd
00:10:25:00 men’s tournament is underway
00;11:06:00 an old style ‘Smiths’ clock in the clubhouse
00:11:36:00 a man with what might be a ‘press’ or media card in his hat
00:11:56:00 tables set for dining with particularly impressive flower arrangements
00:12:29:00 hats and speeches
00:12:52:00 women’s tournament begins
00:13:02:00 a great shot of all bowlers rolling balls into the centre of the green where the white ball (kitty or jack) sits and congratulating the winner
00:13:47:00 mixed gender tournament followed by views of bowlers at their game
00:16:54:00 the outside of the Wangaratta Club
00:20:24:00 a great example of a men’s knitted vest from the era, worn over a shirt and tie
00:20:37:00 poster for ‘Bowling Carnival Australia Day Week-End’ (1957) followed by a bowling venue with covered seats for spectators
00:21:30:00 a score board
00:22:00:00 a close-up of a laughing bowler smiles at the camera
00:22:10:00 bowlers drinking beers and shooing flies
00:24:30:00 a very agile man with only one leg and a crutch enters the green and uses his crutch to bowl effortlessly
00:25:58:00 the Australian flag flies
00:26:01:00 a bowler, cigarette in his mouth, uses his polishing cloth to clean the ball followed by a double arm amputee, also with cigarette in mouth, who bowls a ball toward the camera
00:27:01:00 bowlers gathered on the lawn cheering and raising their hats
00:30:24:00 lovely old weatherboard buildings in the background of the bowling
00:30:34:00 drinking soft drinks at the club house where one woman bowler puts on a bit of a show for the camera
00:34:48:00 poster for ‘Wangaratta Bowling Carnival Australia Day Week-End’ (1961)
00:36:21:00 a very cheery chap takes his hat off to the camera
00:38:41:00 the Corowa Bowling Club in a garden setting followed by scenes of bowling

results.title: [Ted Parsons Home Movies: Reel 8]
results.brief_description:
Ted Parsons was a keen amateur filmmaker of the 1940s to 1960s. Ted’s films feature life in and around the Victorian regional city of Wangaratta post-war. This was a period of prosperity and optimism largely due to a successful textile industry that took Wangaratta from a small country town to major rural city, declared in 1959.

Ted captures the many sporting and social events, venues and clubs, holidays and travel along with scenes of everyday life. The collection also shows the broader issues faced by country people such as the regular flooding events around the Ovens and King Rivers.

Wangaratta’s success story as a manufacturing town traces the path of post-war migration and the accompanying growth of Australia’s economy, which makes these films particularly interesting.

The Ted Parsons Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s grandson Barry Parsons. The films have been made on 16mm film.

In this film, titled ‘Just Roaming’, Ted tells the story of a road trip through Victoria. The Parsons travel through Mount Hotham and Myrtleford, down to Melbourne and then back through Bairnsdale and Paynesville on the south coast.

A feature is the footage of the Gliding Club of Victoria, including female pilots, and historic buildings in Melbourne such as the Shrine of Remembrance and Ormond College at the University of Melbourne. There are beautiful scenes of the Victorian countryside throughout.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 title cards ‘E.J. Parsons Presents’, ‘Just Roaming’
00:00:11:00 a 1950s car leaves the driveway of a brick house and drives down a country road
00:00:35:00 flooded roads and paddocks, uprooted trees in the river
00:01:30:00 a visit to the Hume Dam (formerly known as the Hume Weir) including scenes of Lake Hume
00:02:55:00 man with binoculars, looking out to snow covered mountains
00:03:28:00 two women and a man playing with snowballs
00:04:27:00 a man and woman wade through the snow; woman playfully flashing her underwear to the camera
00:04:50:00 snowy countryside
00:06:33:00 the Hotham Heights Hotel in Mount Hotham, with guests on the balcony looking out over the railings
00:06:51:00 bleached white gum trees and yellow buttercups
00:07:33:00 beautiful views across the mountain ranges
00:08:59:00 a clock tower
00:09:18:00 road sign ‘Myrtleford Please Slow Down’
00:09:27:00 a helicoptor landing in a field, followed by footage of gliders taking off and landing
00:10:27:00 logo ‘Gliding Club of Vict.’ on a wing
00:10:33:00 two young men seated in a glider, smiling and waving at the camera
00:10:59:00 a yellow glider taking off
00:11:19:00 young woman in a glider
00:11:57:00 gardens
00:13:14:00 bridge over the Yarra River, Melbourne, with a church spire in the background
00:13:33:00 the Shrine of Remembrance, Melbourne
00:14:18:00 boys in a red row boat on the Yarra
00:14:25:00 Ormond College, University of Melbourne
00:14:38:00 flowers
00:16:11:00 feeding the seagulls at the beach
00:17:16:00 farm paddocks
00:17:28:00 scenic shot of three people on a rocky outcrop
00:17:43:00 sign for ‘Bairnsdale Please Slow Down’ followed by scenes in the country town
00:18:22:00 a unicycle mounted on a white brick wall
00:18:29:00 the Technical School, Bairnsdale
00:20:34:00 road sign ‘Paynesville Please Slow Down’
00:20:55:00 two women walking along the beach
00:21:32:00 view from a boat on the river
00:22:52:00 boat named ‘Krunulla’
00:24:05:00 poplar and pine trees
00:27:09:00 title card ‘Springtime’ followed by scenery in country and footage of farm animals

results.title: [Ted Parsons Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
Ted Parsons was a keen amateur filmmaker of the 1940s to 1960s. Ted’s films feature life in and around the Victorian regional city of Wangaratta post-war. This was a period of prosperity and optimism largely due to a successful textile industry that took Wangaratta from a small country town to major rural city, declared in 1959.

Ted captures the many sporting and social events, venues and clubs, holidays and travel along with scenes of everyday life. The collection also shows the broader issues faced by country people such as the regular flooding events around the Ovens and King Rivers.

Wangaratta’s success story as a manufacturing town traces the path of post-war migration and the accompanying growth of Australia’s economy, which makes these films particularly interesting.

The Ted Parsons Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s grandson Barry Parsons. The films have been made on 16mm film.

This film takes place on the Jubilee Golf Course in Wangaratta, in its original location on a property on Yarrawonga Road. The club was established in 1935 and in 1963 moved to its present location on Wangandary Road. Ted was President of the Jubilee Golf Club from 1939 to 1955, as shown by a plaque in a cigarette box he received. The film features scenes of the locals playing games of golf and the 1956 Grand Tournament, and features some great examples of 1950s sporting fashion.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 sign ‘Jubilee Golf Club’
00:00:14:00 scenes of the golf course and golfers teeing off
00:01:28:00 women chatting at the weatherboard club building
00:01:46:00 four female golfers cross the course with their golf clubs, wearing pleated skirts and cardigans
00:02:07:00 view up the hill to golfers amongst the trees
00:02:42:00 a group of golfers under a large tree; two women tee off while a group of men look on
00:03:24:00 views across the course
00:05:35:00 stylish golfer in brown check skirt and pink cardigan
00:06:27:00 two men in woollen flat caps
00:06:44:00 golfers gathered outside the golf club, a modest weatherboard building
00:06:53:00 poster for ‘Grand Tournament Wangaratta Jubilee Golf Club’
00:07:49:00 several men tee off in front of the club house as crowd applauds
00:08:36:00 championship board
00:09:02:00 presentation table set up with flowers, six glasses on a silver platter and wooden cigarette box
00:09:13:00 focus on cigarette box with interior sign ‘Presented to E.J. Parsons’
00:09:25:00 more views of golfers on the course

results.title: [Ted Parsons Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
Ted Parsons was a keen amateur filmmaker of the 1940s to 1960s. Ted’s films feature life in and around the Victorian regional city of Wangaratta post-war. This was a period of prosperity and optimism largely due to a successful textile industry that took Wangaratta from a small country town to major rural city, declared in 1959.

Ted captures the many sporting and social events, venues and clubs, holidays and travel along with scenes of everyday life. The collection also shows the broader issues faced by country people such as the regular flooding events around the Ovens and King Rivers.

Wangaratta’s success story as a manufacturing town traces the path of post-war migration and the accompanying growth of Australia’s economy, which makes these films particularly interesting.

The Ted Parsons Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s grandson Barry Parsons. The films have been made on 16mm film.

In this film, Ted captures a trip to Queensland and New South Wales. The film features scenes of holidaying in Queensland, touring around Surfers Paradise, Brisbane, the Sunshine Coast and Coffs Harbour, before travelling down the East Coast from Sydney to Eden and Lakes Entrance. The film includes memorable scenes such as a show of aqua ballet and water ski stunts in Surfers Paradise, dolphins in the Pet Porpoise Pool in Coffs Harbour, historic buildings in Brisbane and fruit farms on the Sunshine Coast.

Of particular interest is Lennon’s Hotel in Broadbeach, which was one of the earliest hotels in Surfers Paradise. At the time, there were few buildings around and the hotel was surrounded by stretches of sand dunes and unsealed roads. It would become the site of the current ‘Oasis Shopping Centre’.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:04:00 title ‘Queensland Gold Coast 1961’ followed by a sequence where travel brochures are tossed over the title card for hotels and destinations including Brampton Island and Surfers Paradise
00:00:23:00 looking toward Lennon’s Hotel, a very colourful, modern 1960s style roadside hotel
00:00:50:00 sign ‘Welcome to Surfers Paradise’
00:00:55:00 scenes around the pool at the hotel including women sunbaking in bikinis
00:01:32:00 sign ‘KR Darling Downs Bacon’ above a shopping plaza
00:02:37:00 the bridge to Chevron Island in Queensland
00:02:54:00 sign in dry grassland for ‘Shopping Centre Here’
00:03:24:00 handpainted sign for ‘Water Ski Revue and Aqua Ballet’ in Surfers Paradise Gardens
00:03:48:00 scenes of spectators on grassy slopes and the performers on the waterskiing show
00:04:41:00 a woman with a full head of hair ‘curlers’ which was a not uncommon look in the 1960s
00:04:51:00 a woman in costume for the aqua ballet, wearing a blue feathered tutu
00:05:04:00 various waterskiing stunts entertain the appreciative crowd
00:06:22:00 Mount Coot-Tha in Brisbane, a mountain with panoramic views over the city
00:08:14:00 traffic on a main road lined with palm trees
00:09:38:00 view of Brisbane City Hall
00:10:00:00 view of the Queensland National Art Gallery in its former premises on Gregory Terrace where it operated from 1931 to 1974
00:10:25:00 sign for the ‘Lone Pine Koala Sanctuary estd. 1927’
00:10:37:00 a koala riding on the back of a German Shepherd dog, hugging its neck
00:11:35:00 view of the grand sandstone Forgan Smith Building at the University of Queensland
00:13:26:00 exterior of the Buderim Ginger Growers Co-Op’s original ‘Merrybud’ factory, west of Mooloolaba on the Sunshine Coast
00:13:48:00 fruit farms, including strawberry fields and pineapple groves
00:17:00:00 fruit pickers and workers in the cane fields
00:20:11:00 kite surfer on the river
00:20:57:00 bougainvillea and two women in the gardens
00:22:00:00 banana plants
00:22:37:00 title card ‘Caloundra’
00:22:45:00 exterior of the Reef Hotel
00:23:34:00 large ship arriving on the coast
00:24:02:00 title card ‘Coolangatta’
00:24:05:00 exterior of the Kirra Beach Hotel
00:24:39:00 the Natureland Zoological Gardens
00:28:38:00 swimming and snorkelling with 1950s examples of oxygen tanks
00:29:37:00 exterior view of the George Gilltrap’s Auto Museum with displays of early twentieth century cars and trucks
00:30:48:00 a demonstration of a 1913 fire engine with a group of firemen dressed in uniform, watched by a crowd of onlookers
00:31:50:00 men pumping the fire hose
00:33:40:00 the Pet Porpoise Pool in Coffs Harbour, a small aquarium
00:35:07:00 visitors feeding dolphins, leaping up to catch fish from people’s hands
00:37:29:00 sign for ‘Galapagos Island Giant Tortoise’ named Harry
00:38:47:00 sign for ‘The Sanctuary’ across a river
00:38:53:00 rosellas feeding
00:39:16:00 two women feeding rosellas from bowls, birds landing on their heads and arms
00:39:36:00 a toddler screaming as a kangaroo paws its head
00:40:32:00 the Terranora Lakes Country Club Estate with golf course and swimming pool
00:41:30:00 the Hornibrook Bridge, a heritage-listed bridge built by Manuel Hornibrook in the early 1930s crossing Bramble Bay
00:42:39:00 the Sydney Harbour Bridge
00:42:52:00 Macquarie Lightstation, Vaucluse, which was Australia’s first lighthouse
00:44:27:00 focused views of the Sydney Harbour Bridge, followed by views across the harbour
00:46:09:00 title card reads ‘Eden’
00:46:21:00 a campfire on the beach with a billy boiling
00:47:05:00 title card ‘Lakes Entrance’ followed by views over the estuary
00:47:51:00 fisherman pulling fish from a net on a dinghy
00:48:55:00 roadside picnic with table set up and playpen for a toddler
00:49:58:00 cooking sausages and bacon over stones
00:50:30:00 title card ‘The End’

results.title: [Taronga Park; Sydney Harbour Bridge; The Great Barrier Reef; Peeping at Perth]
results.creator_credit: Eric Merton, Kodak Cinegraph and Perier Films
results.brief_description:
This film contains four short tourism films edited together, possibly by Ted Parsons.

The first film shows Taronga Zoological Park in Sydney, New South Wales, which was opened to the public in 1916 as a popular tourist destination. The segment shows various species of animals, in particular Australian marsupials (including kangaroos and koalas) and reptiles (including a goanna and a green python). The animals are introduced with title cards.

The second section of film shows the Sydney Harbour Bridge and Sydney beaches. The film shows the arched bridge, including views from the top of it, as well as surfing at Bondi, coastal views of Palm Beach and surf lifesaving at Manly.

The third segment shows close-ups of rockpools by the Great Barrier Reef, including crustaceans, sea snails and starfish. It also shows wildlife, including birds and turtles, along the beaches in Queensland.

In the fourth section, the highlights of Perth, Western Australia are shown. The film shows views across the Perth city, King’s Park, the buildings in London Court and the grand buildings of the University of Western Australia.
results.title_for_label: [Taronga Park; Sydney Harbour Bridge; The Great Barrier Reef; Peeping at Perth]
results.creator_credit_for_label: Eric Merton, Kodak Cinegraph and Perier Films

The first film shows Taronga Zoological Park in Sydney, New South Wales, which was opened to the public in 1916 as a popular tourist destination. The segment shows various species of animals, in particular Australian marsupials (including kangaroos and koalas) and reptiles (including a goanna and a green python). The animals are introduced with title cards.

The second section of film shows the Sydney Harbour Bridge and Sydney beaches. The film shows the arched bridge, including views from the top of it, as well as surfing at Bondi, coastal views of Palm Beach and surf lifesaving at Manly.

The third segment shows close-ups of rockpools by the Great Barrier Reef, including crustaceans, sea snails and starfish. It also shows wildlife, including birds and turtles, along the beaches in Queensland.

In the fourth section, the highlights of Perth, Western Australia are shown. The film shows views across the Perth city, King’s Park, the buildings in London Court and the grand buildings of the University of Western Australia.

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 14]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 14 contains footage of the royal tour visiting Warragul and the Latrobe Valley, followed by a visit to the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research.

Detailed Description Reel 14:

Opens with Title “Warragul”, followed by footage of Queen and Duke exiting railway station (?) and at 00:00:20:00 entering car. 00:00:30:00 flag-waving crowd of children, Queen and Duke mounting dais and waving to crowd. 00:00:43:00 Queen making speech. 00:00:55:00 child presents flowers. 00:01:09:00 locals presented. 00:01:38:00 footage is of crowd along tracks from moving train. 00:01:45:00 footage is of train itself moving along tracks and a distance shot as train moves through very flat grasslands. 00:02:04:00 Title “Visit of His Royal Highness to the University of Melbourne”, followed by very brief footage of flag flying over (presumably) a Melbourne University building. 00:02:17:00 Title “Visit of His Royal Highness to the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research”, followed by shots of the Institute buildings at Royal Melbourne Hospital. 00:03:12:00 the Duke arrives in open car, and greets waiting crowd and children before entering building, where we see some Institute equipment and staff at work. More footage of crowd outside. 00:03:59:00 the Duke exits, moves to car and is driven away.

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 3 focuses on the day the Queen and Duke arrived in Melbourne, and consists mainly of short sections of footage, much of which is also seen in other Reels of this Collection.

Detailed Description Reel 3:

Opens with aerial view of motorcade at top of Bourke Street, Melbourne, (probably leaving Parliament House). At 00:00:11:00 footage switches to Essendon Airport, with officials and police arriving in car and on motorbikes: 00:00:31:00 Crowds are seen waiting for the Queen’s arrival. 00:00:41:00 Arrival of Victorian Governor Sir Dallas Brooks. 00:00:50:00 Flinders Naval Depot Band. 00:01:07:00 footage of crowds along streets from moving car. 00:01:12:00 Queen and Duke walking across tarmac at Essendon Airport. 00:01:20:00 photographers filming the crowds from a moving car. 00:01:24:00 back at Essendon Airport, assembled sailors. 00:01:30:00 close-ups of various officials at, and leaving, Airport. 00:02:25:00 Queen and Duke exiting aeroplane. 00:02:34:00 Queen and Duke reviewing assembled sailors. 00:02:55:00 Queen and Duke in car beginning to leave airport, crowds running to view car. 00:03:07:00 close-up of luggage. 00:03:10:00 staff exiting plane. 00:03:35:00 drive past Essendon Town Hall with crowds on balcony of Town Hall and lining streets. 00:04:00:00 Crowds in street. 00:04:11:00 Queen and Duke on dais, Mayor making a speech. 00:05:08:00 street scene (probably in Essendon), with large crowd in process of dispersing. 00:05:18:00 cars leaving Essendon Town Hall. 00:05:35:00 crowd on steps of State Parliament shot from moving car. 00:05:51:00 crowds behind barriers lining CBD streets. 00:06:12:00 close-up of Henry Bolte, then leader of the Opposition Victorian Liberal Party, on street outside Parliament House. 00:06:27:00 close-up of Queen and Duke getting into car. 00:06:54:00 close-up of people in crowd with spires of St Patrick’s Cathedral in background. 00:07:37:00 State Parliament building, assembled police. 00:07:41:00 people watching from the top of the Imperial Hotel (still extant on the corner Bourke and Spring Streets, Melbourne), and a “Molina’s” sign can be seen (indicating Melbourne’s famous Molina’s Cafe). 00:07:49:00 close-up of workman affixing red carpet to steps of State Parliament; as a stray dog wanders past. 00:07:54:00 Queen’s car approaching State Parliament, crowds outside Parliament building. 00:08:50:00 a man vacuums the red-carpet laid outside Parliament building. 00:09:35:00 Queen and Duke exiting their car outside State Parliament. 00:10:00:00 the Victorian parliamentary Mace and Black Rod are carried up the steps of State Parliament, with Queen and Duke following. 00:10:38:00 Mace and Black Rod are carried down the steps again.

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 16]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

In Reel 16 the royal couple visit regional Victorian towns; including ‘behind the scenes’ shots of press and radio recording the tour, and the enthusiastic welcome given by the citizens of rural Victoria.

Detailed Description Reel 16:

Opens with Title “Shepparton”, followed by footage of crowds waiting to see the royal visitors. 00:00:26:00 Queen and Duke arrive and meet some locals. 00:00:36:00 Queen, Duke and local Mayor mount dais for speeches (by Mayor and Queen). 00:00:58:00 Queen and Duke re-enter car for drive through town; crowds line streets. Camera stays focussed on car, with little footage of Shepparton streets. 00:01:13:00 shot includes some local buildings and shops and a sign for the “P & O Cafe” is visible. 00:01:18:00 Title “Tatura”, followed by footage of crowds waiting to see the royal visitors, including school children in uniform. 00:01:39:00 Queen and Duke arrive in car, meet some locals. 00:02:16:00 Queen makes speech from dais. 00:02:19:00 “Tatura” sign at local railway station segues straight into footage of crowds along tracks taken from moving train, then views of orchards (or vines?) and paddocks also shot from moving train. 00:03:12:00 Title “Echuca”, followed by a shot of the Murray River with buildings and boats moored at banks. 00:03:23:00 street parade of children (beneath a series of floral arches), including Brownies and Girl Guides in uniform. 00:03:41:00 waiting crowds shot from moving train with some town some buildings visible. 00:03:49:00 Queen and Duke get into car. 00:03:58:00 Queen and Duke listening to speech (by Mayor). 00:04:13:00 good shot of assembled press photographers standing for national anthem. 00:04:22:00 Queen makes speech. 00:04:33:00 back into car for street tour. Footage of local streets and buildings, and crowds lining roadway. 00:05:11:00 car arrives at railway station. 00:05:19:00 close-up of Queen and Duke waving from back of train. 00:05:26:00 Title “Rochester”, followed by footage of waiting crowds. 00:05:44:00 Boy Scouts in uniform marching past a public building in background (possibly school or town hall). 00:05:49:00 footage of “Royal” train coming into station, Queen and Duke disembark. 00:06:07:00 Queen and Duke meet and chat with locals, and walk along crowd-lined street. The flies are particularly bad, and both Queen and Duke are seen waving flies away between waving at the crowd. 00:06:28:00 street sign “Welcome Shire of Rochester”. 00:06:57:00 back to the railway station and onto train. Crowds waving and cheering. 00:07:30:00 good shot of reporter talking into microphone. 00:07:40:00 Title ” Bendigo”, followed by footage of waiting crowds from moving train, Queen emerging from railway station. 00:07:55:00 with Mayor in robes and chain. More footage of crowds and motorcade through streets follows. 00:08:41:00 appears to arrive at sportsground with crowds including Girl Guides and Brownies. 00:09:05:00 Queen addresses crowd from dais. 00:09:10:00 shot of press photographers kneeling and crouched on grass. 00:09:29:00 back in the car, Duke appears to remove something from back of Queen’s dress. 00:09:50:00 at decorated railway station (“Parcels Office and Cloak Room” sign). 00:10:03:00 car arrives at station. 00:10:22:00 footage of people along tracks and houses from moving train, orchards and landscape.

Crowds waving and cheering. 00:07:30:00 good shot of reporter talking into microphone. 00:07:40:00 Title ” Bendigo”, followed by footage of waiting crowds from moving train, Queen emerging from railway station. 00:07:55:00 with Mayor in robes and chain. More footage of crowds and motorcade through streets follows. 00:08:41:00 appears to arrive at sportsground with crowds including Girl Guides and Brownies. 00:09:05:00 Queen addresses crowd from dais. 00:09:10:00 shot of press photographers kneeling and crouched on grass. 00:09:29:00 back in the car, Duke appears to remove something from back of Queen’s dress. 00:09:50:00 at decorated railway station (“Parcels Office and Cloak Room” sign). 00:10:03:00 car arrives at station. 00:10:22:00 footage of people along tracks and houses from moving train, orchards and landscape.

Opens with Title “Shepparton”, followed by footage of crowds waiting to see the royal visitors. 00:00:26:00 Queen and Duke arrive and meet some locals. 00:00:36:00 Queen, Duke and local Mayor mount dais for speeches (by Mayor and Queen). 00:00:58:00 Queen and Duke re-enter car for drive through town; crowds line streets. results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 2 of the collection dwells on the decorations that celebrated the visit, in the streets and on the buildings of Melbourne’s CBD, then shows the officials and staff responsible for the planning and conduct of the tour at work inside the (now demolished) Geological Museum. We are shown the Victorian police reinforcements arranged for the visit being addressed by their commanders, before the scene shifts to Essendon Airport and the preparations for touchdown of the ‘royal’ plane.

Detailed Description Reel 2:

Opens with Title “Melbourne: City decorations”, followed by footage of Melbourne CBD streets and buildings sporting decorations for the visit (Flinders Street Railway Station from Elizabeth Street, Myer Emporium, Swanston Street, the Leviathan Building, trams and cars). 00:00:54:00 shot of old Princes Bridge Railway Station (partially obscured). 00:01:15:00 The Commercial Bank of Australia. 00:01:25:00 decorated Melbourne Town Hall. 00:01:31:0 Foy and Gibson building. 00:01:35:00 emu and kangaroo diorama. 00:01:59:0 Title “Royal Visit Offices: Geological Museum” followed by footage of the exterior of the (now demolished) building in Macarthur Street, and scenes of the staff at work inside. 00:03:32:00 Title “Police Re-Inforcements: The Chief Commissioner and the Chief Secretary address 750 men prior to the visit.” followed by footage of uniformed police being addressed by the commanders. 00:04:25:00 Title “Official Landing & Reception: Melbourne Airport - Overseas Terminal Wednesday, 24th. February, 1954” followed by footage of preparations for the arrival, men in top-hats, men in uniform and waiting crowd. 00:05:12:00 Flinders Naval Depot Band. 00:05:36:00 arrival and close-up of Victorian Governor Sir Dallas Brooks as he exits car. 00:05:44:00 Flinders Naval Depot Band and sailors marching. 00:06:04:00 plane taxis onto tarmac, close-up of royal coat of arms on plane, which is flying the Royal Standard. Camera pans across “Australian National Airways Pty Ltd - Royal Mail” written on side of plane. Exit stairs are wheeled up to plane, and the Queen and Duke step out.
